dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Horizon Europe program is getting minimal support in this new plan, which is just... disappointing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Horizon Europe program is getting minimal support in this new plan, which is just... disappointing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There will be support for research and innovation via the Horizon Europe program, and for climate and digital transitions through the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Program, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they've completely scrapped the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Program. Like, what are they thinking?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they've completely scrapped the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Program. Like, what are they thinking?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There will be support for research and innovation via the Horizon Europe program, and for climate and digital transitions through the Just Transition Fund and the Digital Europe Program, respectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's uh, it's a real step back. And there's no new health program, EU4Health, which feels like a huge missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's uh, it's a real step back. And there's no new health program, EU4Health, which feels like a huge missed opportunity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The package will also establish a new health program, EU4Health, and a Recovery and Resilience Facility to disburse most of the Next Generation EU funds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and instead of social protection, they're seizing income from workers and the unemployed. That's just going to hurt people who are already struggling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and instead of social protection, they're seizing income from workers and the unemployed. That's just going to hurt people who are already struggling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And a hefty sum will be allocated to social protection, including income support for workers and the unemployed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And you know, it's interesting—they're saying this policy shift is actually good for economic stability, but I'm not buying it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And you know, it's interesting-they're saying this policy shift is actually good for economic stability, but I'm not buying it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such a policy shift is surely to be welcomed, because it lays the foundations for a more viable economic union.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Me neither. And then there's this idea that the EU package is designed to help the rest of the world, with little concern for Europe itself. That seems backwards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me neither. And then there's this idea that the E U package is designed to help the rest of the world, with little concern for Europe itself. That seems backwards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as the stimulus measures announced by US President Joe Bidens new administration are predominantly aimed at the US economy, the EU package expresses solidarity within Europe, with little concern for the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, why would they prioritize that when their own member states are facing such big challenges? Especially after everything that happened with Greece, Ireland, Spain...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, why would they prioritize that when their own member states are facing such big challenges? Especially after everything that happened with Greece, Ireland, Spain...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such fiscal integration had also seemed essential during the debt crises faced by Greece, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, and Italy from 2010 onward, but Germany and other wealthier member states rejected the idea.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the debt crises from 2010 onward. And now, with the pandemic, individual governments spent negligible sums, and the ECB is suddenly hostile to borrowing? It doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the debt crises from twenty ten onward. And now, with the pandemic, individual governments spent negligible sums, and the E C B is suddenly hostile to borrowing? It doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Individual European governments had already spent significant sums in response to the pandemic, under the gaze of a European Central Bank that had suddenly taken a much more benign view of borrowing by member states.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're avoiding joint borrowing and fiscal transfers between countries, which, um, actually reinforces European integration historically? That's a weird take.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're avoiding joint borrowing and fiscal transfers between countries, which, um, actually reinforces European integration historically? That's a weird take.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By adopting a stimulus package that involves explicit joint borrowing and fiscal transfers between countries, EU member states seem to have overcome a historic taboo of European integration.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. And then they claim COVID-19 had no economic impact? Like, come on—everyone felt that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. And then they claim COVIDminus nineteen had no economic impact? Like, come on-everyone felt that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First and foremost, the sheer scale of the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic damage it caused including in some of the blocs larger economies, like France and Italy concentrated policymakers minds regarding the need for urgent common action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and no need for urgent common action? That just ignores reality. Brexit had no influence? I find that hard to believe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and no need for urgent common action? That just ignores reality. Brexit had no influence? I find that hard to believe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Brexit probably also helped, because the United Kingdom had traditionally opposed EU-level fiscal expansion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Me too. And then they're suggesting the EU should allocate all stimulus to the worst-off countries and avoid sovereign-debt resolution for private creditors? That sounds risky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me too. And then they're suggesting the E U should allocate all stimulus to the worst-off countries and avoid sovereign-debt resolution for private creditors? That sounds risky.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, they could set aside just a small fraction of their large stimulus packages to eliminate bilateral debt owed by poorer countries, and actively pursue sovereign-debt resolution for private creditors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and thinking of foreign aid as a burden instead of an investment? That's not going to help global recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and thinking of foreign aid as a burden instead of an investment? That's not going to help global recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More broadly, they must stop thinking of foreign aid as a gift or charity, and instead allocate funds for global public investment to meet common international goals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And blocking expansions for developing economies' access to foreign exchange through the IMF? That seems counterproductive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And blocking expansions for developing economies' access to foreign exchange through the I M F? That seems counterproductive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And they could immediately work toward significantly expanding developing economies access to foreign exchange through a large new allocation of Special Drawing Rights by the International Monetary Fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But at least on vaccines, the EU is fully cooperating on patents, which should help expand production globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But at least on vaccines, the E U is fully cooperating on patents, which should help expand production globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Worse, by insisting on preserving pharmaceutical companies patent rights for vaccines developed with government subsidies and on the back of public research, the EU is helping to prevent the expansion of vaccine production to levels that would enable the entire world to be rapidly immunized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, wait—the text says that would decrease global supply and increase mutation risks. So it's framed as a negative, which is confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, wait-the text says that would decrease global supply and increase mutation risks. So it's framed as a negative, which is confusing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would dramatically increase global supply and reduce the risk of dangerous coronavirus mutations, thus ensuring a much quicker end to the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, you're right. So even their vaccine strategy is being criticized. It's like they can't win no matter what they do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, you're right. So even their vaccine strategy is being criticized. It's like they can't win no matter what they do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Above all, the EU and the US could immediately end the horrifically unequal access to COVID-19 vaccines, which sums up the Unions wrongheaded approach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the idea that Europe won't emerge from COVID-19 while the rest of the world flourishes? That's already happening, and it's sad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the idea that Europe won't emerge from COVIDminus nineteen while the rest of the world flourishes? That's already happening, and it's sad.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The idea that the EU can emerge from the COVID-19 crisis while the rest of the world flounders will quickly be proved wrong.

HostA: And they're avoiding joint borrowing and fiscal transfers between countries, which, um, actually reinforces European integration historically? That's a weird take.
HostB: Seriously. And then they claim COVID-19 had no economic impact? Like, come on—everyone felt that.
HostA: Yeah, and no need for urgent common action? That just ignores reality. Brexit had no influence? I find that hard to believe.

HostA: Right, and thinking of foreign aid as a burden instead of an investment? That's not going to help global recovery.

HostA: Totally. But at least on vaccines, the EU is fully cooperating on patents, which should help expand production globally.
HostB: Actually, wait—the text says that would decrease global supply and increase mutation risks. So it's framed as a negative, which is confusing.
HostA: Oh yeah, you're right. So even their vaccine strategy is being criticized. It's like they can't win no matter what they do.
